conclusion: Determine the propagation time of light in the prism.
Light enters the prism at an angle of 45 degrees and exits perpendicular to the AC side.
The vertex angle of the prism is 30 degrees.
The angle of incidence at the first face is 45 degrees.
Light will undergo refraction at the first face and then reflect off the second face.
Using Snell's law at the first face: n1 sin i = n2 sin r.
n1 is the refractive index of the air (approximately 1), n2 is the refractive index of the prism.
The angle of incidence at the second face is 90 degrees - gamma.
The light will be reflected if the angle of incidence is greater than the critical angle.
Since it exits perpendicular to the AC side, the angle of incidence must be such that the light is reflected and then refracts out.
The distance s traveled by the light in the prism is the hypotenuse of a right triangle with legs L/2 and s sin gamma.
The total path length is s = L / (2 cos gamma).
The time taken for the light to travel this distance is t = s / v = s / (n2 c / n1) = (s n1) / (n2 c).
Using Snell's law: sin 45 degrees = n2 sin 60 degrees.
The time taken is t = (L sqrt(3)) / (sqrt(2) c).
The final answer is (L sqrt(3)) / (sqrt(2) c).
